history.content:
Before taking CS 61C, I watched the first half of Fall 15 lectures, by Asanovic and Stojanovic. Last semester, I also sat in a few 61C lectures with Katz for fun. (I am taking 61C now).

I can't comment on Pister and Wawrzynek, but Asanovic and Katz are extremely qualified 61C professors. We here at Berkeley are lucky to have them. They don't act like it - they are humble people - but they are world-class researchers in computer architecture. And I mean top 10 computer architecture researchers worldwide. Prof. Asanovic built RISC-V, the first successful open source ISA, which is being adopted globally. Prof. Katz created RAID (Redundant Arrays of Inexpensive Disks), which is the reason your hard disk rarely loses data. Google Drive, Amazon Drive, Microsoft Cloud Drive, etc - in fact any cloud service - wouldn't exist with Prof. Katz's work.

Both are also interesting and very clear lecturers. They don't just read off the slides, but also supplement slides with their personal experience. Every lecture, you will walk away feeling you learned something new. I would 100% recommend taking the course with them.

Before taking CS 61C, I watched the first half of Fall 15 lectures, by Asanovic and Stojanovic. Last semester, I also sat in a few 61C lectures with Katz for fun. (I am taking 61C now).

I can't comment on Pister and Wawrzynek, but Asanovic and Katz are extremely qualified 61C professors. We here at Berkeley are lucky to have them. They don't act like it - they are humble people - but they are world-class researchers in computer architecture. And I mean top 10 computer architecture researchers worldwide. Prof. Asanovic built RISC-V, the first successful open source ISA, which is being adopted globally. Prof. Katz created RAID (Redundant Arrays of Inexpensive Disks), which is the reason your hard disk rarely loses data. Google Drive, Amazon Drive, Microsoft Cloud Drive, etc - in fact any cloud service - wouldn't exist with Prof. Katz's work.

children.subject: I haven't heard that. What do you mean by not fair?
I've heard that the large portion of the final exam in Fall 2016 was from a very small part of the syllabus that was barely emphasized
I disagree. It was a tough exam that deviated from past exams. But it was not unfair.
In what ways did it deviate from past exams?

As someone who gave that exam, I wouldn't exactly call it unfair, but it was certainly much much harder than other exams, and was a major deviation as well (it did focus largely on a very small topic as one of the Anons above said, trying to link it across to other topics in the course; the problem was most students, myself included, had not spent much time reviewing said topic, and so were completely lost for large sections of the exam).
I've heard Prof Katz's exams are not fair. How true is that?
Wawryznek is pretty good, and exams were fair/similar to what previous exams were like. I don't know much about Pister though

history.content:
Hi, so for my schedule I can want to fit in 61C either FA17 or SP18.  

When I take it depends on certain factors and classes for the most part, but I also wanted to know about the professors teaching it.

For fall, it will be taught by Krste Asanovic and Randy Katz, 

Spring is Kristofer Pister and John Wawrzynek.

What are your recommendations/experiences with these professors.

Thanks!
history.subject: CS 61C Professors
